commentBody: Please stop with all the Pips references!
Mercy, Mercy, Mercy, as Cannonball Addely’s SAX might say.  That was a cute Wednesday.  Will people like it. IHOPESO. IMnotLYING!

Seemed like a Tuesday for a Wednesday.   But there was some nice fill and nice clueing.  I especially enjoyed the clue for EDEN.  

Made ya look
Made ya look
Now you’re in
The baby book.

Main grumble: the crossing for L_A and _EROS was one I had to run the alphabet on. 

Luckily that didn't take long...

A nice little dash of Canadiana, not just ONT and PEI, but also AEROS. And while it was far too easy to complain about in general, I will say nobody in the history of humanity has spelled NARKED with a K.

(I'm sure somebody is already rushing to Google to prove me wrong, but I blissfully do not care.)

I recall when my then wife and I were living large as DINKs. But soon enough, we became SITCOM. 

Single Income, Two Children, Oppressive Mortgage.

No, I didn't like this.  Resent is a strong word but I did not enjoy being immediately directed to a much lower revealer clue while starting to complete the first section.  Right off the bat, 20A is requiring us to consider or fill in 54A and 57A.  No thanks.

It didn't prove necessary but it left a bad taste in my mouth.  It turned out to be one of those puzzles where the theme was extraneous to solving it.  The theme should complement a puzzle and play an active part in solving it.  Not here.  And the silly diagonal digits.  Sigh.

Anyhow, this was suitably Wednesday quick, although I had TenK instead of TenG for a little while....

I could have lived without the "ya" instead of "you", but okay.  The twice in a lifetime clue was interesting.

I would guess that many others enjoyed it more than I.
Am I crazy or did today feel more like a Tuesday and yesterday feel more like a Wednesday?

Is it selective memory or maybe archives I’m doing. But

PIP and ELM are in every puzzle I do. 
It used to be ENO, ONO, and MAA/BAA. 

I’ve never watched even one episode of survivor. 
But simply voting someone off the island is called blindsiding them, generically?  
Blindside has to be a setup where the unsuspecting target gets punked by their teammates. Assuming there are teammates. 

Alone. Now that’s a sweet outdoor reality series.

Once again, some comments are not appearing without clicking on the time stamp.

This time is not just replies to replies.  This time it's a reply to the OP.

Sigh.  How I used to idolized the New York Times.

I did it, but not sure what I did.  One I didn't do was figure out the theme.  Switched some letters and got a star.  

Thanks, Peter.

I loved this puzzle!
It was different, with a creative theme, and interesting, with a variety of fill.

The twice in a lifetime clue had me holding my breath as I solved the crosses, waiting for some kind of deep and mind-blowing revelation, something that someone had thought of and that no one else ever had and that now I, too, would be privy to.

—  LONG I? Come again? 
Oh well. Fire wasn't discovered anew and my brain didn't rattle and shake, but I sure got at least a smile out of it.

Thank you so much, Mr Collins. I truly enjoyed solving your puzzle!

"How come that button isn't working?"
"Yeah, I just can't put my finger on it."

(These puns are getting out of hand.)

Kudos to Peter Collins for coming up with this worthy mid-week theme.  

I had to derive the revealer (MIDDLE x INDEX) from the fill before getting the theme entries. Icing on this cake - the witty clue for LONGI.

A fun puzzle, perfect difficulty for mid week IMO. 

I found NARKED a bit jarring/contrived but we can't expect all puzzles to be perfect can we? (except Robyn Weintraub's! When do we get another from her?!! 😍)

I feel like there was another puzzle in the last few years with a fingers theme. I don't have the energy to look for it right now, maybe tomorrow.

So for NARKS naysayers, no I’ve never heard of it either but if you look it up it is a real spelling (primarily in Britain?) and in fairness the clue did say var. That whole corner’s a bit clunky with both fingers there and the word CROSSED, I guarantee the constructor racked their brain to find cleaner fill and this was the best they could do in service to the theme. Not my favorite Wednesday but not bad and I won’t call foul.

As an added bonus the constructor can thank the crossword gods that the word MIDDLE is a bit longer than the word INDEX as are the fingers. Although I suppose if it were the other way around they could have tried to fit in POINTER.

Clever theme. I was able to deduce the theme and finished filling in MIDDLE and INDEX which helped with all of those answers. My last entry was the LAA/AEROS cross. I entered LAA from just the L, but then I backed out the As when the second letter down was an E. I’m unfamiliar with that Nestle product, but when that A was the last man standing, I figured it had to be right and plugged it back in. Voila…happy music and gold star ⭐️ Thank you, Peter. 

Happy hump day, Crosslandia. 🐪

Cultural differences: crossing fingers is not really a thing over here. When wishing for a positive outcome, we may make a fist with our thumbs in the middle of our palms. It's called "trzymać kciuki", to hold one's thumbs. I don't believe in luck, and I'm not superstitious at all, yet I sometimes catch myself doing it.

Of course I know the expression "fingers crossed", but I had no idea crossing fingers may also be an indication of lying. The concept seems weird to me. Why would you make a gesture that may be spotted, ruining your deception? Lying is about body language, too, not only words. Is it about lying to yourself about your lie? "Hey, I'm not *really* lying!!! See, my fingers are crossed!" If so, it's just hypocrisy.

The puzzle's fill was confusing to me, in quite a few spots. Seeing the same unfamiliar musician in two places didn't spark joy. In the end I needed one lookup, of the actress in the NW corner. Not knowing a thing about "Survivor" and my apparently not being on the constructor's wavelength meant I just could not make progress there without outside help. Googling DAVIS was what I needed to finish that final area of the puzzle.

"Narked" was a truly awful bit of crosswordese. I enjoyed the theme and the puzzle otherwise.

Even the briefest of googles shows that it's more commonly used in recent history as meaning "irritated". This seems like a bit of an editing miss. Cluing it this way really "narked" me.
don't usually post a comment but that was a terrific puzzle, well done to the author and editors. Thanks for being such a fun way to start the day (this and every)

I found this pretty challenging for a Wednesday. The NW corner was tough for me, although Viola DAVIS should have been a quicker gimme.

I do not, however, resent NARKED. We were warned that it was a variant, which means brace yourself for a crazy spelling. I take that as a clue to move on to the next word, as I do with any clue that ends with "on scoreboards." The root in this case is narc, from narcotics. The problem with "narced" is that rules of pronunciation tell us to rhyme that word with parsed. (See forced, paced, lanced, and narcissus, but not arced.) Plus the crosses were easy enough. 

Ok, go ahead, tell me I'm wrong.
Fun puzzle! And fun fact - in Vietnam crossing your fingers is a rude gesture, essentially flipping someone off.
32 Across, Business Magnate, I had only the ___on. 1st word that came to mind was 'felon.' Lol

First time commenter here…just felt I had to defend NARKED! Not sure if this is a British thing, but to me that’s if anything the standard spelling… (maybe would have been fairer if they’d said “to Brits” instead of var). Anyway, I always enjoy these rare moments that make up for all the times this crossword is incomprehensible to your friends across the sea!

Fabulous crossword. Interesting to read of the varied meanings of the CROSSED FINGERS. I’m aware of  I HOPE/IM LYING. Fascinating to hear it’s a rude gesture in Vietnam (@CB) and that it isn’t a thing at all in Poland (@Andrzej).

Another crossword that wasn't too difficult for me. What's happening?
I had to look up DAVIS, I'm useless with famous people, and PACSUN was unknown, and LAA. 

I did know PENELOPE though. I used to think it was pronounced penny-lope, until I heard it (Lady Penelope). Like Her-me-own for Hermione. They weren't names that my friends had as a child. 

Enjoyable.
Fun theme, good puzzle! Got stuck trying to work HELENOFTROY into the middle (thinking "a rebus? On a *Wednesday*?"), but I was getting my epics mixed up
I have worked in pro volleyball for almost a decade and I have never heard of a DINK. I was stumped for the longest time.

Like any card carrying crossword cheater, of course I focused on the crossed circles, worked out the reveal answers and figured I was done!  Why bother with the rest of the puzzle, right?

Wrong!  20 and 22 A a pleasant and fun surprise.  My heLEN for the Nobelist and no clue on the clothing store chain did make that top part a bit stickier.  

Nicely done and thanks.

Fun Tuesday puzzle. Typical slow start for me, but then things fell together from the crosses. Finally tumbling to the trick was a nice 'aha' moment and that's always a nice touch. Two thumbs up (and yeah - that's been an answer in a couple of puzzles). A couple of appropriate puzzle finds today. First a Wednesday from July 25, 2018 by Emily Carroll. The reveal in that one: "Gestured rudely ... or what this puzzle's circles have done?" FLIPPEDTHEBIRD And a couple of theme answers with theme related sequences circled: POL(TERGE)ISTS (EGRET) GOLD(ENARC)HES (CRANE) Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/25/2018&g=56&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ...

With 104 themed NYT puzzles, Peter has an inventive mind, and it was out in full force today.

There were double-plays in the cluing: Two with rhymes (luck/struck, Maine/Spain), two with Cannonball Adderly, two with “squeal”, and a pair of Canadian provinces.

Also, he crafted a grid accommodating three elements -- The what-crossed-fingers-signify answers on top, the circled letters in the middle, and the two-answer revealer at the bottom. Wow!

And by the way, it would have been much easier to simply cross a horizontal and vertical MIDDLE and INDEX, but Peter crossed them diagonally, which, as Peter says in his notes, makes cleanly filling a grid much tougher.  Yet he succeeded admirably.

Oh, and that magnificent riddle clue – [What’s heard exactly twice in a lifetime?]!  Not only fooled me (Hi, Sotto Voce!), but gave me a glorious combo of “D’oh!” and standing O.  All this plus brain-pleasing rub from a couple of no-knows and a handful of had-to-wait-for crosses.

Cleverness and mastery in the box today on top of a sweet solve.  What a delight!  Thank you, Peter.
My fave was MADEYALOOK, loved the puzzle.
Nice tough Wednesday! Had to look up the actress, otherwise clean. Great clues and a clever theme.

This was so a good puzzle! Thanks, Peter! Did you know that the ancestors of Red Pandas are from the Southern Appalachias? Our Western North Carolina Nature Center has a pair. “History: The red panda’s ancient cousin once lived in the Western North Carolina region. Bristol’s Panda (Pristinailurus bristoli) is an ancient North American relative of the living red panda whose fossils have been discovered at the Gray Archeological Site in the Southern Appalachian Mountains of Tennessee. Western North Carolina’s climate and ecosystem is almost identical to the lower mountain forests of Central Asia where red pandas currently live. The red panda is an endangered species with less than 10,000 (possibly as few as 2,500) of them in the wild. Their natural space is shrinking as more and more forests are destroyed by logging and the spread of agriculture.” https://wildwnc.org/animals/red-panda/ Hope all y’all have a great Wednesday!
If everyone had been involved in the drug culture in the late 60s or early 70s, then there would be no comments about NARKED today.

This satisfying puzzle, Cannonball Adderley’s Autumn Leaves, and a strong cup of coffee was a perfect start to the day. 

Happy fall, y’all.

What amazes me is how many comments are about NARKED.

It seems like every puzzle has an entry like that.

Odysseus' words to his beloved at their reunion are perhaps the most moving and beautiful(and perfectly-metered) lines in all of literature:

Ye crossed your fingers(like silken rope)
Ye did not abandon hope
You ate cantaloupe
Pushed the envelope
And rassled an antelope
(how I love that Greek trope) 
My rosy-fingered dope
My loyal, clever Penelope

What a cool puzzle...but what else would we expect of Peter A. Collins?  

Did I know you could CROSS your FINGERS to (supposedly) get away with LYING?  Must have missed that one.  I do remember a spate of fibbing around age 13--attempting to avoid what I saw as prying and over-supervising; it was really too much work to keep up the dissembling.  

I just tried it, only to discover I can't really manage crossing my fingers any more.  It never worked anyway.

For God's sakes people, can't you just accept that you don't know everything and move on?  If you must, tell the world you have never heard of it (I know I do occasionally), but please don't assume that the clue is wrong.

PhysDaughter is here working the puzzle with one eye (the disparity being so great that she is closing her newly-repaired eye and looking at things through her (thick) glasses with the other eye...  Anyway, I pointed out an error she made, only to learn that we both have an error to do with the candy bar crossing some team...  and we both guessed wrongly.  Dang.  
I don't eat candy, so PFFT! And the Baseball Season should have been over ere this!  I guessed ZEROS.
(Sour grapes!)
Very pleased to see the Survivor shout-out on the day of this season's premiere!
Challenging but I managed.  Felt tough but much more fair than yesterday's proper noun fest
If you have absolutely no alibi or defense to a RAT squealing on you, does that make you STARK NARKED?

My favorite scene in the "Odyssey" occurs when Odysseus, still disguised as a beggar, offers advice to his wife PENELOPE.  Her handmaiden, Eurycleia, comes to wash the beggar's feet and recognizes her old master by the scar on his thigh.  In the split second between the moment of recognition and her reaction to it, Homer gives us a beautiful flashback in which he retells how he got the scar (during a boar hunt) and how Odysseus got his name (from his maternal grandfather).
And then Homer abruptly alters the tone of the scene as Odysseus claps his hand over the slave's mouth and threatens her with death if she reveals his identity.

Wow!  That Homer fellow sure could compose a scene!

I was just listening to Gladys Knight's version of "Heard it through the Grapevine", and I was thinking that I just can't get enough PIPS! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WWvwP72FuVg And "Midnight Train to Georgia": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rhnRyQCeqXI More cowbell??? I say, "More Pips!"

PacSun was a blast from the past. During the 80’s and 90’s we bought most of the clothes for our two sons there. The San Jose store was always busy : they routinely had more revenue per square foot than any other store in the mall.

To use "madeyalook" in a sentence frequently heard in a 50's childhood:
"Madeyalook, you dirty crook, you stole your mother's pocketbook. You turned it in, you turned it out. You made it into sauerkraut."
I liked it!! (fingers uncrossed).

My first thought on the clothing/surf shop clue was RonJon, which is pretty much local all over Florida. Obviously, that didn't work, and it didn't take long to come up with PACSUN, which I've seen at a number of malls around the country. My other goof was TEN K instead of TEN G, which had me puzzling about 22A for a while.

Thanks for the fun, Peter!

This was entertaining and a decent challenge! I was almost stumped a few times, but I managed to finish (a bit slowly) without looking anything up. Loved the theme, but I especially enjoyed the Cannonball Adderley references! Thanks for a fun Wednesday morning puzzle!

Nice puzzle with a clever theme and a lot of thematic content. And the fill was still quite solid, though a bit heavy on proper nouns for my liking.

Not familiar with PACSUN or NARKED, and surprised that YA for YOU was not signaled in the clue for MADEYALOOK. But got these entries easily enough from the crosses.

Liked all four of the long vertical entries, and also the pairings of EASYA with LONGI and PEI with ONT.

Very enjoyable puzzle.
I really enjoyed the puzzle.  A small nitpick: narc is short for narcotics and informing on someone to to narc on them, not nark on them (47 down).

There is a convention in crossword solving that has long irked me and today you have the pleasure of learning of my irk. 
I'm speaking of a clue such as:
-- What's heard exactly twice in a lifetime? --
This is outright cheating. Any educated adult, nay, teen, knows that "lifetime" or "a lifetime" ought to be in quotes. 
The idea that I am meant to look for letters of the alphabet rather than things heard in an actual lifetime is simply a bridge too far to carry, to mix a metaphor for all who wish to buy a bridge. 
Of course, it would be rather easy to solve if the clue were: 
-- What's heard exactly twice in "A lifetime." 
What to do? 1. Live with my irk. I am no fan of this solution. 2. Change the convention. Big fan. 3. Don't clue "LONGI" lest you risk my wrath.
Hey, what happened to my educational (and slightly snarky) post about P.E.I.? Admittedly, I've never been there, although I have been to Nova Scotia, which is lovely this time of year.

I'm always a fan of clues that speak to each other and this puzzle delivered some great ones! Squealed and squealer. Two Cannonball Adderly clue, lining up on the left side of the board. Two Odyssey references on top of one another. Most populous and least populous Canadian provinces. A good puzzle doesn't need to be this extra, but it just shows the constructor's commitment to detail. It's not just a fill that supports the theme–it's a fill with it's own intentions.

Because who wouldn't want pictures of beautiful landscapes with their Mozart? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XeZ40LdFB6Y (It's the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields/Marriner recording, so you know it's good.) Aeros bars are creepy. Fun puzzle, Mr. Collins! Go Blue!

Overall fun puzzle. Wasn’t too thrilled with “ten g” answer for the clue “100 c-notes” though.

Since c-notes is plural in its abbreviate / slang context, ten g’s should have been as well. 

Nobody says “yo I got ten g”.

“Ten k” would have been a more appropriate answer here.

Sorry this stuff bothers me!
Nice work Peter.  👋🏼

A fun solve! I'm always happy to be reminded of the existence of REDPANDAS. What terrifically adorable and unusual looking creatures. 

As it happens, red pandas have an additional digit on their front paws, giving them six "fingers." (These are technically not fingers, but elongated wrist bones, which allow them to better grip bamboo.) However, I don't think they have the dexterity to cross them!
Obviously I've been spelling the word "narkotics" wrong this entire time.

Thanks for an outstanding puzzle, Peter Collins. 👏🏻
Loved the secret in the circles. 💋
Pretty easy but I liked it! ELM needs to be retired though.
I joyfully, and with great confidence, typed in Wakanda and Forever for 20 and 22 across. Sad to see they did not work with crossings.

Sailed through except for the last letter: the A in AEROS and also LAA. Would never have gotten!
Very clever puzzle. Thank you, Peter A. Collins.

I know it's a play on words, but BLONDES being the answer for "Lightheaded sorts?" just perpetuates an awful stereotype. In addition, the B just happened to be the ender for DUMB?
I expect better from the Times.

Admittedly it did take me awhile to see the double meaning in "lightheaded," but I can't say I love that clue for BLONDES, especially when it's crossed at the beginning by DUMB. Perhaps "Sandy and strawberry," or "Golden ales," or "Titular 1953 penchant"
And repeating words we just saw a day or two ago.

@Brendan

More Gladys?
@Dan This seems to happen pretty frequently. Years ago, I caught up using them archived puzzles. It was not uncommon, which surprised me.
@Brendan It’s called product placement. (I do love the new Pips game, though!)
@Dan I’m also seeing instances where the same odd word/clue gets repeated in a Mini from the next day.

@Brendan

I'm just going to chill out over here with this bag of Kit Kat Minis....
@Lige  🤣

@Brendan I was just listening to Gladys Knight's version of "Heard it through the Grapevine", and I was thinking that I just can't get enough PIPS! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WWvwP72FuVg And "Midnight Train to Georgia": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rhnRyQCeqXI More cowbell??? I say, "More Pips!"
@Isabeau me too. That was my last square.

@Isabeau
I hope you started from the top of the alphabet…

@Isabeau

Same here. Although I didn’t start at the beginning and somehow skipped “A”, so that ended up being a very anti-climactic Reveal Square. And I was having such a good time until then. 😖

@Isabeau I was so fixated on how either Crunch or Krackel could possibly fit in 52D (random Wednesday rebus side quest?!) I didn’t stop to think that they are full of rice, not air. (And one of them is a Hershey product:)
@Isabeau I kept thinking ZEROS as there is a ZERO bar

@Shrike

Not caring if you are wrong or no is an essential quality

@Francis

I intended to hit Cancel and instead hit Submit.

I'm glad I didn't still have the incendiary statement I decided against.

Note to self:  Clear everything before tying to cancel--you might hit the wrong button, and there's no going back.

@Sid

Exactly - two different words.  And the older one with a K has never meant squealed and is not a variant of narc.  So Shrike is (at least mostly) right.

@B

MW does actually as the first definition, chiefly British, meaning “stool pigeon”. In any case I think Francis’ rant was probably more about the poster not caring if they were right or not, not if they were. I would have the same rant if I were so inclined.

@SP

Yes, for the noun but NOT for the verb.  That's what I said.  :)
@B  Based on Wiktionary at least, nark is valid as a verb with past tense narked, so narked and squealed are synonyms, no?

@SP

I dunno, I think there’s something to be said for letting the insignificant minutiae go…
@Shrike, I'm used to "nark" being a noun as in "copper's nark", but one of the sources I looked at suggests that the verb is slightly older than the noun.

@Isaac P

Which put you in the state of DEPRAVITY - Don't Even Pretend Retirement And Vacation In Twenty Years.
@B I used the index & middle to figure out the other 4, so my experience with the theme was very different than yours! And I thought it was a great puzzle!

@B

For the record I certainly did use the theme to solve. And aren’t most revealers put at the bottom (or at least the middle?)
@Francis What, indeed? Either a kinder world or … dogs and cats living together, mass hysteria https://youtu.be/-9NMt42il4Q?si=cuNTIYQCfddDrfwY

@B

I see your point. Often you can try to solve the themes without the revealer and then the revealer helps to tie them together later. But I can think of a lot of puzzles where the revealer is referred to early, or you can’t really understand the theme answer until you get to the revealer whether implicitly referred to or not. Think about the wonderful Star Trek puzzle lately. All those down entries really assumed you figured out the theme early to make sense, and I don’t remember anyone complaining. In any case, for my solve, IHOPESO  which made me think about what that theme could be, then got FINGERS and figured out fingers crossed, while also seeing the fingers in the grid—it all happened pretty organically for me and I don’t remember feeling much different about it than most other puzzles.

@B
I’ve actually requested constructors make the upper left more difficult, because I find that if I figure that out quickly then the rest is often more boring. Not that I generally don’t solve puzzles from top to bottom and left to right, but I don’t mind jumping around if I have to.

@The X-Phile

I am living dangerously.  

It's a struggle being a person who relies heavily on sarcasm.  It's harder to clarify in writing than in person.

I know I could use emojis and such, and I have.  But somehow that strikes me as being like telling a solver that there a rebuses in the puzzle.  Takes some of the fun away.

@Yael

I solved today's puzzle in 15 minutes with one lookup (about 3 minutes under my Wednesday average). Yesterday I needed 17 minutes (ca. 7 minutes more than my Tuesday average) and several lookups.

@Weak

You forgot ERA.

@Weak
I guess we did have LAA (Los Angeles angels of Anaheim). So MAA/BAA was represented…

@Weak

As an admitted and unabashed Survivor fan, everyone gets voted off the island when they leave. Sometimes they more or less know it’s coming. But part of the game may be to vote people off without them knowing it—and yes, when that happens it’s called a blindside. That is generally because you don’t want them to have time to talk to or make deals with others to try to save themselves, or because they may have found an “idol” which gives them immunity if they play it and you want to make sure they don’t. How’s that for reality geekiness?
@Weak I think DAB, USED, ADEPT, PDA, ALOHA and LSAT all used recently

@B

Could not agree with you more about reality TV.  But I was afraid to say anything like that, so I'm glad you did.

@Weak 
Blindside:Vote::
Jellybean:Candy
(All blindsides are votes but not all votes are blindsides)
Looking forward to Mike White's reappearance on tonight's season premiere

@Long walks n sunsets

You won’t. The 50th season is in the spring, this is 49

@Francis

Wanted to take a minute to thank you for putting me onto “Schmigadoon”. I binged watched it in two days.

For everyone else, this is a great example of what I love about crosswords and this forum—if you pay attention you can be exposed to all sorts of knowledge and experiences you may otherwise miss. In this case we got from Sunday’s theme—Kit Kats—to the Kit Kat club in Cabaret to musical theater in general to this wonderful show I somehow hadn’t heard about. It’s an amazing satire of musical theatre that somehow strikes the right balance between skewering the genre and revering it, with a fabulous cast featuring my favorites Alan Cummings and Kristen Chenoweth, throwing in Aaron Tveit and Arianna DEBOSE (who  coincidentally was also in Sunday’s puzzle) for good measure. Cicely Strong’s off-color version of Do-Re-Mi  was the funniest thing I’ve seen on TV for a long time.

All that’s a roundabout way not only to thank Francis but also remind everyone that if you keep an open mind you can expand your world with crosswords—another reason to embrace “Naticks”, read and learn about them, rather than just worry about them breaking your streak.

@SP

Glad you enjoyed it!

I, too, thought it perfectly straddled the line of spoof and homage.  

"Did somebody say, 'Corn Puddin'?"  The show had me well snagged by this point.

@Francis

My second favorite bit was the take off of Sweeney Todd and the orphans. Spot on!!

@Francis

No, but unless I click on the thing that says see the new previewed way we're making everything better for you, I don't see anything at all unless I click on the timestamps. Ridiculous!
@sotto voce I loved the twice in a lifetime clue as well. And it also kind of reminded me of City Slickers. https://youtu.be/DOjV_YTSp0I?si=aSeYdvYzqmy7nD_3 ☺️

@sotto voce

That was definitely a noteworthy clue.  

And your description of how your excitement was building up...mwah...it is cinematic worthy of Cecil B.  DeMille.

Yeah, kind of an anticlimax.  A joke about language and pronunciation.  

But a brilliant clue.

@Francis

Cinematic worthy, eh? Ha! Too funny, but thank you!

Anticlimax is the perfect word for what happened next. 
But I got that smile out of it.
And I'll remember that clue for a long time.

@sotto voce

I wish you the very best of luck and I hope that you will let me know if you do figure it out!! ☺️😘

@sotto @HJ

“One thing.”  That reminds me of a guy I knew many years ago, back in grad school. I was complaining about someone, probably a professor, and this guy said, “well, you’ve got to realize, Professor X’s ‘basic problem’ is Y. I don’t remember X or Y. But that comment led to this guy telling me his fundamental philosophy of life:

“Everyone has a Basic Problem. You have one, I have one, she has one, he has one. Everyone. The trick is, (1) accept that; (2) for each person, figure out what that person’s Basic Problem is and decide how you can live with/work with/work around it.”

After thinking about it, I realized that his determination about someone’s BP wouldn’t necessarily be the same as the one I would diagnose for that person. Your determination about someone’s BP says as much about you as it does about them.

But, imo, that doesn’t diminish one bit the usefulness of that guy’s “one-main-thing” in his approach to life.

@Warren

An interesting concept. I'll have to think more about it.

Your take on it, as I see it, would require much communication between the parties involved, which would be wonderful for closer and deeper relationships.

His take, as I understand it, is a simple *you* decide/look for another's BP and work around that. You never even communicate with them about any if it. Might work really well in a work scenario for self-preservation and sanity.

Thanks for this!

@sotto voce

Hah! As usual, you are very kind. On reflection, that was one of those stories where my kids would laugh and say, “um, good story, dad (eye roll).” I guess it just stuck with me because of his belief that there was “one thing” that made his life work.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@SP

It doesn't bother me at all, since language evolves, and it doesn't take much to make me think it's possible that anyone trying to write the mostly-spoken verb "narc" in the past tense might change the c to a k to make it conform to normal pronunciation rules.

Unlike the "soft g before e, i and y" rule, which has many exceptions, the soft c rule is fairly strict.  Some older verbs, like picnic, panic and traffic, take an additional k before adding -ed or -ing.  Verbs like arc may not, perhaps because of an aversion to putting -ck after a consonant.  But I'd be fine with "arked" for "arced"; I don't think there's much danger of people thinking of Noah's boat in that case.

Maybe we should ban the letter c altogether, and replace it with k and s everywhere.

@Andrzej Similar in German/Germany. We "press our thumbs" for good luck, but I think we do cross our fingers behind our backs to signal we are lying. Although being an English/German Translator and consuming a ton of American media, I more and more struggle with what is my "original" culture and what is my adopted one.

@Jane Wheelaghan Superstitions are funny. I am not very superstitious in many cases, but “knock on wood” is one I grew up with and I actually get a little nervous if I forget to say/symbolically do it if talking about something that I want to keep going well. It is because of having it be ever present as a kid. As a result I try to be really mindful of what I say around my kids, including when explaining superstitions, to try to create distance for them so they don’t feel bound by any in the same way.

@Jane Wheelaghan

Superstition is very common over here. The main coach of our national football team 5 or 10 years ago notoriously forbade his players to sleep under a sloping roof before a game because, get this, it brings bad luck... Nobody laughed in his face about it, either.

@Andrzej
Amazing! 
Perhaps I am underestimating superstitions. I've heard that wearing  'lucky' items of clothing is still important to some people.

I think that when I was a child there were a lot more mentions of superstition than I hear now - 
eg not to walk under a ladder 
if you spill salt, throw some over your left shoulder (that's to do with the devil lurking there), 
"see a pin and pick it up, then all day you'll have good luck"
breaking a mirror brings 7 years bad luck. 

I have 2 young grandsons and never mention superstitions!

By George, I think you've got it.

@Francis Linguist here! The rule came to English by way of Norman French and still mostly applies to words of French origin. I assume there were some perfectly good s-words in Old English that may have been altered by various attempts at spelling reform over the years, as there are many other spelling rules that have done exactly that (see the examples of blue (nee 'bleu') and imbue ('imbeue') vs clue ('klew') and hue ('hew')), but curiously I can't remember any off the top of my head, and Google's AI summary of every search query is "helping" (i.e., getting in the way).

@Bruce Mic seems completely legit to me, it's slang just like narc. But if you attached the mic to a person, I'm not sure it's clear to say you miced the person. I'd pick miked. 

Full disclaimer here, I'm not even remotely a linguist, just a reader. So I looked it up at MW. Mic and mike are both acceptable nouns that mean microphone, but the verb form is mike. Of course, narc and nark is muddier, as thrashed about here.

@Nora you are correct. The letter K is primarily used for the /k/ sound to avoid the "soft C" before the vowels E, I, and Y. Therefore I have always spelled it NARKED in my head, regardless of knowing it is derived from narcotics. Narsed would sound wrong and that’s how I would pronounce it if it were spelled with a C.
